item.title: How does the Shadow DOM appear in the accessibility tree?
item.dc:creator: Russ Weakley
item.description: A screen reader cannot interact with the shadow DOM unless the browser exposes the internal elements that users can actually operate. To make this work, browsers flatten the shadow tree when building the accessibility tree.
item.content:encoded:
Browsers face a problem: screen readers need to understand what's inside web components. Without flattening, screen readers would not be able to see the real anything inside the shadow root.

But all of that is hidden behind the Shadow DOM boundary.

So how do browsers solve this? To make this work, browsers flatten the shadow tree when building the accessibility tree.

item.title: What is an accumulated text bucket?
item.dc:creator: Russ Weakley
item.description: Learn how browsers build accessible names using the idea of an accumulated text bucket, and why some naming rules empty and replace it.
item.content:encoded:
Throughout Accessible Name and Description Computation specification, you'll see the term accumulated text.

But what does accumulated text actually mean?

When the browser tries to compute an accessible name — for example, by following aria-labelledby references or collecting text from child nodes — the algorithm needs a temporary place to store the text it gathers.

Think of this as an accumulated text bucket — a container the browser fills with bits of text from different sources before deciding what the final name should be.

item.title: What are DOM mutations?
item.dc:creator: Russ Weakley
item.description: DOM mutations are any changes to the DOM tree. These mutations can happen with or without JavaScript.
item.content:encoded:
DOM mutations are any changes to the document's node tree. These mutations can happen with or without JavaScript and are central to how modern interfaces update.

The article covers layout impact, accessibility impact, and how browsers detect and respond to these changes.
